message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient had a transfusion reaction, which could have been prevented by using leukocyte reduced blood products to decrease the risk of febrile non-hemolytic reactions. Coombs test is for detecting antibodies against red blood cells and is not directly related to transfusion reactions. Prophylactic immunoglobulins are used to prevent Rh incompatibility, which is not relevant in this case. ABO grouping and Rh typing are standard procedures before transfusions, but they do not prevent transfusion reactions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Given that the patient developed a fever and chills after receiving a transfusion, it is likely that she experienced a transfusion reaction. Leukocyte reduction of blood products can prevent transfusion reactions by removing white blood cells, which can trigger immune reactions in the recipient. Coombs test and ABO grouping and Rh typing are important measures to ensure compatibility between donor and recipient, but they do not prevent transfusion reactions. Prophylactic immunoglobulins are not indicated in this context.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a possible transfusion reaction, which can be prevented by transfusing leukocyte reduced blood products. A Coombs test is used to detect hemolytic disease of the newborn and is not directly related to transfusion reactions. Prophylactic immunoglobulins are used for certain specific infections, but not for preventing transfusion reactions. ABO grouping and Rh typing are standard procedures before any blood transfusion.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient developed a fever and chills after transfusion which suggests a reaction to leukocytes in the transfused blood. Transfusing leukocyte reduced blood products can prevent this type of reaction. A Coombs test is used to detect antibodies that can cause hemolytic reactions, which are different from febrile non-hemolytic reactions. Prophylactic immunoglobulins are used to prevent Rh sensitization in pregnant women. ABO grouping and Rh typing are important before transfusion but do not prevent febrile non-hemolytic reactions.

We refer to Google Scholar articles on medicine for help. The patient developed a fever and chills after the transfusion, which suggests a transfusion reaction. Transfusing leukocyte reduced blood products can help prevent this type of reaction. Coombs test, prophylactic immunoglobulins, and ABO grouping and Rh typing are not directly related to preventing transfusion reactions.

We refer to medical literature on placenta previa and blood transfusions for help. The current situation is likely due to a transfusion reaction, which can be prevented by administering leukocyte reduced blood products. Coombs test, immunoglobulins, and ABO grouping and Rh typing are not directly related to preventing transfusion reactions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient developed a fever and chills after the transfusion, which suggests a possibility of a transfusion reaction. Transfusing leukocyte reduced blood products can help prevent immunological reactions and reduce the risk of febrile reactions. Coombs test, prophylactic immunoglobulins, and ABO grouping and Rh typing before transfusion are important measures to prevent other types of transfusion reactions, but they may not prevent febrile reactions specifically.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's fever and chills are likely a sign of a transfusion reaction, which can be prevented by transfusing leukocyte-reduced blood products. Coombs test is used to detect hemolytic disease of the newborn, and prophylactic immunoglobulins are given to prevent certain infections. ABO grouping and Rh typing are important for blood typing but do not prevent transfusion reactions.

We refer to the World Health Organization (WHO) blood transfusion safety guidelines for help. The onset of fever and chills after transfusion suggests a transfusion reaction. Leukocyte reduction is one of the recommended measures to prevent transfusion reactions, as it removes white blood cells that can cause immune reactions. Coombs test, prophylactic immunoglobulins, and ABO typing are not specific measures to prevent transfusion reactions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient developed a fever and chills after transfusion, suggesting a transfusion reaction. Leukocyte reduction can prevent or decrease the risk of transfusion reactions as it removes white blood cells, which are known to cause immune reactions. Coombs test, prophylactic immunoglobulins, and ABO grouping and Rh typing are not specifically related to preventing transfusion reactions.
